For the journal clubs, the TA said they expected us to spend ~6h a week to read and analyse the papers but honestly we all spend minimum 10h on them to do so. The subjects were also so specific that you always had to do additional research to understand most of it well enough to then only be able to criticise and analyse the paper. The last four weeks are dedicated to group projects (so no journal clubs) which was very different but was kinda fun. Just also took forever :,). We had to re-do a computational data analysis from a given paper and a methodology retrieval from another one. The data analysis took definitely more time and effort. Problem was each group had a different paper so you could not really discuss and compare. The methodology retrieval was okay and quite easy to do actually. That said, in the end they gave really good grades because they knew they were going hard on us so it's quite easy have a good grade (>5), and the subject is really interesting but just be prepared to spend lots of time and energy on this, and mostly on your own, even if the TA's very available for questions and directions.

I took this course in 2023-2024 with professor Dimitri Wyss and although I really enjoyed the content, I think the course was given in a too formal of a way without much emphasis on the intuition and motivation behind the material (Why do we need groups ? What was the motivation for their introduction in mathematics ? How do they relate to the study of symmetries ?... ) The course was thus taught in a very classical way and i think it is worth looking for insight and try by yourself to understand the motivation behind the concepts. As for the exercise sheets, they are extremely interesting but sometimes very hard. Don't be discouraged, the exam is usually much more doable. Nonetheless, it is a good idea to do them all and try to get the most out of them as they give a good understanding of the material, you don't have that many past exams with their corrections, plus the results of the series can be used in the exams and might be very usefull.
